messages: fd686aa46da1e08426b09b3eaf579ed2 (10:01): morning/TZ_specific_greeting
d1ecb99b19140444b80e4035bfe0dd67 (10:08): Afternoon, brendang
fd686aa46da1e08426b09b3eaf579ed2 (10:27): G'Day boyd
7ef291c89ad915978b203d427919cfbb (10:31): brendang, i met one of your coutrymen yesterday he has high hopes, he wants to port  zfs to linux/ppc  by looking at the specs.
fd686aa46da1e08426b09b3eaf579ed2 (10:33): how long would he have to look at the specs for this to magically occur? ;)
fd686aa46da1e08426b09b3eaf579ed2 (10:34): I'll look at the specs for Gran Turismo 4 for a while, and hope it appears on Solaris
7ef291c89ad915978b203d427919cfbb (10:34): he's in brisbane, he hasn't even seen  solaris express run because he only has a ppc box.
fd686aa46da1e08426b09b3eaf579ed2 (10:34): ahh, a Queenslander
7ef291c89ad915978b203d427919cfbb (10:35): well he did seem pretty well versed in the some of the finer parts of zfs, it was obvious he read at least the first part of the zfs on disk format guide
4225cebe45099ecf3a9835e344d0a71f (10:43): i was wondering how opensolaris performs as a home desktop, or is it primarily directed at server implemenntations?
7ef291c89ad915978b203d427919cfbb (10:43): works great if your hardware is supported,,, and zfs rocks  for home use.
4225cebe45099ecf3a9835e344d0a71f (10:45): well, i've read some reviews and i was quite impressed
7ef291c89ad915978b203d427919cfbb (10:46): solaris express community edition has a fairly recent  gnome release i think its  2.14  IIRC
4225cebe45099ecf3a9835e344d0a71f (10:47): so playing encrypted dvd's is no problem?
8c27c6238210e78d0cff9690db08116b (10:47): dthompson, I'm doing prety good with my SXCRs on the desktop
7ef291c89ad915978b203d427919cfbb (10:47): not sure i haven't used my solaris box as a mutlimedia device.. delewis  is the mplayer expert.
4225cebe45099ecf3a9835e344d0a71f (10:50): is sxcr solaris express release?
7ef291c89ad915978b203d427919cfbb (10:50): community release
4225cebe45099ecf3a9835e344d0a71f (10:51): new OS new lingo :)
542ebcbcf6ee466a1780913e2c800716 (10:57): http://www.microsoft.com/windowsserver2003/ <- 3,400,000,000+ users can't be wrong")
7ef291c89ad915978b203d427919cfbb (10:58): brendang, your execsnoop, makes creating zones really interesting.
fd686aa46da1e08426b09b3eaf579ed2 (10:58): yes indeed!
fd686aa46da1e08426b09b3eaf579ed2 (10:58): last I did it, it was around 2,200 processes
7ef291c89ad915978b203d427919cfbb (10:59): and its awesome for debugging shell scripts as well
7ef291c89ad915978b203d427919cfbb (10:59): yeap... it does a lot of work
aa939d032327c8399cf2851d5b0201ed (11:02): hmm.. firefox seems to have far, far more security vulneribilites than IE
7ef291c89ad915978b203d427919cfbb (11:05): Doc, how so...  there has only been 5 patches since  1.5 .0  came out... in 4 months...
aa939d032327c8399cf2851d5b0201ed (11:05): and each fixes double-digits of bugs
7ef291c89ad915978b203d427919cfbb (11:05): the latest oine is for a single bug.
aa939d032327c8399cf2851d5b0201ed (11:06): 48 vuls in 1.5 so far, 26 of which are "critical"
aa939d032327c8399cf2851d5b0201ed (11:06): umm.. you might want to have a look at http://www.mozilla.org/projects/security/known-vulnerabilities.html#firefox1.5.0.5
aa939d032327c8399cf2851d5b0201ed (11:07): the latest fix includes 7 issues which result in remote code execution without unser interaction
7ef291c89ad915978b203d427919cfbb (11:08): okay.. but i still think  firefox is much more secure than IE is.
d1ecb99b19140444b80e4035bfe0dd67 (11:08): By my calc that still leaves 2.4e12 vulns before they catch up.
8c27c6238210e78d0cff9690db08116b (11:08): doc just remember aiee probably has all of the bugs, it's just that redmond won't actually admit to it
aa939d032327c8399cf2851d5b0201ed (11:31): benr: told ya srss didnt work in a zone...
466c8c1fb4fcaa4398b3347fb36f74f0 (11:42): 'morning
